jparsec.ephem.planets.imcce

Class Series96

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.ephem.planets.imcce.Series96

  • public class Series96
extends java.lang.Object
    A class to calculate planetary orbits based on the IMCCE's Series96. A fit to JPL DE403 ephemeris over the interval 1900-2100 (1850-2100 for Neptune and 1700-2100 for Pluto). The interval 1900-2100 is the one when this theory is applicable, because we need the position and velocity of the Earth to obtain geocentric coordinates, and the Series96 theory is limited to years 1900-2100 in this respect.

    Representation of planetary ephemerides by frequency analysis. Application to the five outer planets. Astron. and Astrophys. Suppl. Ser., 109, 191 (1995). J. Chapront, G. Francou - IMCCE (France).

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)

    • Method Detail

      • getGeocentricPosition

        public static double[] getGeocentricPosition(double JD,
                             Target.TARGET planet,
                             double light_time,
                             boolean addSat,
                             ObserverElement obs)
                                      throws JPARSECException
        Get rectangular equatorial geocentric position of a planet in epoch J2000.
        Parameters:
        JD - Julian day in TDB.
        planet - Planet ID.
        light_time - Light time in days.
        addSat - True to add the planetocentric position of the satellite to the position of the planet.
        obs - The observer object. Can be null for the Earth's center.
        Returns:
        Array with x, y, z, (object position) vx, vy, vz (Earth barycentric velocity) coordinates. Note velocity components are those for the Earth (used for aberration correction) not those for the planet relative to the geocenter.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • getHeliocentricEclipticPositionJ2000

        public static double[] getHeliocentricEclipticPositionJ2000(double JD,
                                            Target.TARGET planet)
                                                     throws JPARSECException
        Calculate heliocentric position for a given time (dynamical equinox and ecliptic J2000). Methods from Capitaine et al. are considered.
        Parameters:
        JD - Julian day in TDB. Must be in the range 2341972.5 - 2488092.5 (years 1700 - 2100) for Pluto. For Neptune JD starts at 2396758.5, and for the other planets at 2415020.5. Scale: TDB.
        planet - Object to calculate.
        Returns:
        An array of 6 elements containing the heliocentric rectangular position and velocity of object (mean equinox and ecliptic of J2000).
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • getHeliocentricEquatorialPositionJ2000

        public static double[] getHeliocentricEquatorialPositionJ2000(double JD,
                                              Target.TARGET planet)
                                                       throws JPARSECException
        Calculate heliocentric position for a given time (dynamical equinox and equator J2000).
        Parameters:
        JD - Julian day in TDB. Must be in the range 2341972.5 - 2488092.5 (years 1700 - 2100) for Pluto. For Neptune JD starts at 2396758.5, and for the other planets at 2415020.5. Scale: TDB.
        planet - Object to calculate.
        Returns:
        An array of 6 elements containing the heliocentric rectangular position and velocity of object (mean equinox and equator J2000).
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • isSeries96Available

        public static boolean isSeries96Available()
        Returns true if Series96 method is available in the classpath.
        Returns:
        True or false.

      • getBarycenter

        public static double[] getBarycenter(double JD)
        Obtain rectangular coordinates of the geocentric position of the Earth-Moon Barycenter. Equinox and equator J2000. No limitation exists in the input date. It has been tested that this method has a discrepancy with DE406 close to 200 km (2 degrees) in the position of the barycenter at 3000 B.C., producing errors of several 0.1" only for objects close to Earth.
        Parameters:
        JD - Julian day (TDB).
        Returns:
        Array with x, y, z coordinates.

      • series96Ephemeris

        public static EphemElement series96Ephemeris(TimeElement time,
                             ObserverElement obs,
                             EphemerisElement eph)
                                      throws JPARSECException
        Calculate ephemeris, providing full data. This method uses Series96 theory from the IMCCE, valid between 1900 and 2100. Typical error is about 0.001 arcseconds or below, when comparing to JPL Ephemeris DE403.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object containing the date.
        obs - Observer object containing the observer position.
        eph - Ephemeris object with the target and ephemeris properties.
        Returns:
        Ephem object containing ephemeris data. Rise, set, transit times and maximum elevation fields are not computed in this method, use Ephem class for that.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        For unit testing only.
        Parameters:
        args - Not used.
